Amen!!
On every point. Thank you for this.
No one has any control over whom they are born to, either. You will be just fine.

I'm a Korean-American (not adopted) and agree with others that the separate issues of race and adoption are being conflated. The description about how when the adoptees are in Korea, they don't feel fully Korean, and when they are in the U.S., they don't feel fully American applies to me too. But, between the two, I definitely identify much more as an American, which the adoptees say they cannot because they grew up with white parents. I grew up in the U.S. with *Korean* parents and still feel more American than Korean -- mostly because of how women are treated in Korea. I've only been there twice, but in that short time, I saw how unpleasant it was for women. When I'm in the U.S., I can be me and feel a thousand times more accepted here than in Korea. So, I think the adoptees are feeling the loss of their birth families and somehow equating it to losing Korean culture. But even if you grew up with Korean parents in the U.S., you're still going to lose that culture. My mom watches some Korean dramas and is turned off by some of what she sees because she is more American culturally. She finds the rate of plastic surgery there outrageous, and my whole life has railed again the education system there (even though she excelled in it). Don't imagine that just having parents who are ethnically Korean will mean you grow up culturally Korean. Some ethnic Koreans move to the U.S. and prefer the culture here and would raise their kids that way, as mine did.

Exactly right, BD. Conservatism is backward-looking.

"A conservative is a man with two perfectly good legs who, however, has never learned how to walk forward." -- Franklin D. Roosevelt

This is true, on an individual case by case basis. However, when the practice is institutionalized, then each adoption is contributing to more of the same. Adopting the children out of the country allows that country to not evolve and address its own issues. Continuing to adopt Chinese girls allows the Chinese to continue the practice of devaluing women... until they reach the tipping point where nature has been thrown out of balance by our actions and there are too many men in the population. Our actions have consequences for each child, and it may be in the best interest of the child, without being in the best interest of humanity. Just as overfishing might feed the hungry while destroying the ecosystem in which fish can thrive.

adoption is complicated in any setting.

Yes - a novel written to express the three slants on : do we need to reconnect, should we make up our own identity, or does it matter to do a search if you love your adoptive family. thanks , Deborah A. M. Phillips.

No, I have two sets of parents. No matter what you believe, I was shaped by the woman who gave birth to me, and I could write a book on all the things that prove it, both personally and scientifically. Why is it I have to disown one family in order to honor another? Why is it people believe I dishonor the parents who raised me by wanting to know the ones who created me?
All you have to do to understand this reaction is just read mein kampfe (spelling?). Just my  2 cents worth.

Being a troop leader is labor intensive. Where I live in an impoverished rural community, Girl Scouts has not been part of the family tradition among the majority of the people who live here, and no one has the time to lead a troop while working three minimum wage jobs. There are no troops here. A few years ago, some of my daughter's friends' mothers and I thought we might lead a troop, but then they bailed so I did too. They bailed because they both work in the health professions and were taking weekend professional development classes.

I don't have time either; I work ~50 hours a week and more as a teacher.

It's too bad. I was a Girl Scout from 7 to 17 and then worked for them in paid and volunteer capacities from 17 to 31. I can credit Girl Scouts with the necessary skills for becoming a teacher.

I didn't call you ungrateful or unloving. That was Maggie, to whom I was responding. I bother to make this correction because, as an adoptive parent, I worked (and still do) very hard to support and encourage my adult son to do whatever he needs to do to understand his life story. Nor do I expect him to be any more grateful or loving than a biological child who was raised with love and care.

John - I'm a white woman who lived for a number of year in South East Asia. When I am in "white" countries - the US, Australian, the UK - I feel gender. When I was living in East Asia, I felt my race.

Lovell's observation doesn't revel anything about either of the cultures she was exposed to. It reveals an enormous amount about how pervasively we 'feel' difference - it cuts to the core of who we are.

Big Pharma and Small research is funded at least in part by the US NIH - your tax dollars and mine.
The new method of developing new antibiotics announced last week was funded by NIH and the German Govt at a US university.
The professor who discovered it got to patent it to himself and promptly sold that patent to a big pharma company.
This was for a new METHOD for developing antibiotics, not just a single drug. So now, thanks to your taxes and mine a single company will control how many new drugs will be created.
Your last line is a nonsequitor to your previous. If research is not done well now; how could it be worse with less profit motive pressure?
Big Pharma is also killing people or making them sick via pushing drugs to people that don't need them, and by suppressing the adverse effects.

They do it because they can. Money works that way.

Why can they? Because they paid off our politicians, via high priced lobbying that pretends it isn't corruption.

This isn't a medical problem. It is a political corruption problem.

What if drug companies spent less on research? They won't make any money at all. They are making huge profits, not huge new investments, with these overpricing schemes.

Anyway, medical research is a good thing for government money, if the alternative is the government pays obscene profits for private money to do it. Cut out the middle man. And the corrupt politicians.

@DJS, this wasn't just "climbing a wall" but a highly inspirational demonstration of human courage, perseverance, endurance, determination and teamwork. It was an achievement which shows the best side of the human spirit.

We all need a break from the terrible things in the headlines  - especially you BL. Watching these climbers achieve their amazingly difficult goal gifted me a lightness, joy and a sense of awe that lifted my heart every day after reading the other sobering, exhausting, hope-destroying, sad, sad, sad headlines.

Trust me - I am not resentful of their stamina; I've an excess of it myself and it's admittedly a problem knowing what to do with it all.  I do, however, envy their free time -- nearly three weeks goofing off crawling up a rock like a salamander.  And if 'free climb' distinguishes these chaps from the other 1,000 or so who've scaled El Cap before, perhaps the next fellow can do it in the nude, creating another utterly meaningless "first."

You are so wrong. I carry scars on my neck from a fall where my belay line looped around me. Using ropes for protection is hardly risk free, particularly in an environment as harsh and unforgiving as the Dawn Wall over a period of 19 days. Many things can and do go wrong. Climbers can be injured or killed.
This was a brave and heroic achievement.

You have no idea what you are talking about. I am a Korean adoptee with three children and my oldest in college. They are biracial, they deal with similar issues of identity, your comment invalidates the experiences and potential issues of any person who struggles with identity in a place where race and culture are linked. Whether in our thirties, forties, or beyond - our experiences are valid. It is. It a matter of feeling "sorry" for ourselves. It is a matter of giving a glimpse of our experience and hopefully letting potential future adoptive parents an understanding of what their children may struggle with in the future. Before making such judgements, one hopes you would for a moment have some sense of empathy with the issues raised in the article. Again, unless you have had such an experience - who are you to judge?

Why would they not?  Seems to me that the need for an adopted child to seek out his/her genetic mother/father is a primal urging of every human.  Both of my children (adopted at age 8 days and 4 days, respectively) have taught me that as much as I have offered them skills and values, at the end of the day, the only important thing was how my kids felt.
All happy families are happy in the same way!  Even the multicultural ones!!!

Thank you for this thoughtful and thought-provoking comment. I cannot ever understand your pain and your experience, but your words help just a little bit towards it. I hope as time goes on you find a measure of peace.
She may have been worse off in many ways, yes,  but please don't deny the sorrow of losing one's parents at an early age. She lost a primal connection.

Dear Gail:

You might want to keep an eye on Scott Walker's bald spot.
He claims it's the result of hitting his head on a cabinet
(though it sure looks like male pattern baldness to the rest of us).

If a man will lie about something like that...
he may have a dog, too.

That is our real polarization. Most people won't even vote anymore they are so disgusted with all of them.

Your last two sentences neatly define the very strategy that the far Right, Daddy Warbucks class has been working on since Saint Ronnie, and such as Karl Rove and Grover Norquist and their nasty ilk grabbed the reins. They want to anger and bore and disrespect voters so much that they just give up and then it only take oh 17% to win an election. THAT is the meta-strategy.

Mark Thomason said, "The politicans position themselves with respect to each other in the eyes of donors."

You make an excellent point. I might add that generally only the most politically active members of either party are likely to be so passionate about politics that they donate money or time and vote in primaries -- and they are likely to be more polarized.

The average voter does none of these -- and they are like to be far more central.

Until we get money out of elections, especially the primary cycle, things will never change.

You have the politicians you deserve, because you voted or didn't vote.  The American way of democracy is of course hindered by ugly political philosophy. Like the thought that only the informed and reasonable citizens should vote. And there are a lot of mean structures hindering.  Like your almost totally commercialized political debate. But isn't there first and foremost the kind of individualism you practice? Why being subdued by anyone, especially a collective of ordinary dull people?   Well, The Europeean way has been "United we stand, divided we fall". That is a principle common to the fascist, the Soviet communist, as well as the social-conservative and his or her social-liberal counterpart. It's a principle that has worked more than a century with obviously higher voter turnout than in the US. The political philosophy behind is already mentioned. But of course, one has to ORGANIZE and build ORGANISATIONS that will last through decades.

The largest and most consequential polarization is between the American people who vote or could vote, and the politicans of both parties.

The politicans position themselves with respect to each other in the eyes of donors.

Meanwhile, voters have entirely different priorities and preferences. Those don't matter to politicians. Without donors, they can't even run, and with donors they must obey to remain.

Lobbyists are the enforcers and bag men for donors. There is nobody in and out of politicians' offices for voters, just a parade of bag men and enforcers.

That is our real polarization. Most people won't even vote anymore they are so disgusted with all of them.

As a relatively new adoptive parent, I can say that international adoption is highly intrusive, time consuming and expensive process. Our agency is Holt, which is a wonderful organization. When we went to pick up our child, we met other adoptive parents, and they were sincere, well intentioned, loving people. All wanted to do the right thing for the adoptees.

Now, my wife and I are loving parents to our 4 year old. He is the most wonderful boy. We love him so much, and yes, at first we thought that we would be saving another child from an ophanage, but the truth is that he saved us. We will try to repay him every day with our love and our efforts to be good parents in every way we can.

It is simplistic to say that love is the answer, but it is true. Our boy is from China, and my wife is Filipino American and I Chinese American, so we hope this may shorten the gap with our boy as he tries to understand why and reconcile how we came to him. We will give him the freedom explore his heritage and bloodlines. It's his happiness that matters most.
